Problem 1

Equilateral △ABC with side length 14 is rotated about its center by angle θ, where 0<θ<60°, to form △DEF. See figure. The area of hexagon ADBECF is 913​. What is tan(θ)?

Solution

Let O be the center of △ABC, then it is easy to prove that

∣OA∣​=33​​∣AB∣=3143​​​​

It is easy to prove that

[ADBECF]​=3[△OAD]+3[△OAF]=23​∣OA∣2sin(θ)+23​∣OA∣2sin(120°−θ)=98sin(θ)+98sin(120°−θ)​​

Therefore,

[ADBECF]=913​​⟺sin(θ)+sin(120°−θ)=98913​​⟺21​cos(θ)+23​​sin(θ)=9891​⟺sin(θ+30°)=9891​⟺tan(θ+30°)=9133​​⟺tan(θ)=1153​​​​

Problem 2

Suppose A, B and C are points in the plane with ∣AB∣=40 and ∣AC∣=42, and let x be the length of the line segment from A to the midpoint of BC. Define a function f by letting f(x) be the area of △ABC. Then the domain of f is an open interval (p,q), and the maximum value r of f(x) occurs at x=s. What is p+q+r+s?

Solution

Applying the Triangle Inequality yields that A, B and C forms a triangle iff

∣∣AB∣−∣AC∣∣<∣BC∣<∣AB∣+∣AC∣⟺2<∣BC∣<82

Applying Apollonius’s Theorem yields

x​=21​2∣AB∣2+2∣AC∣2−∣BC∣2​=21​6728−∣BC∣2​​​

Therefore, A, B and C forms a triangle iff

1<x<41

Therefore, p=1,q=41.

f(x)​=[△ABC]=21​∣AB∣∣AC∣sin(∠BAC)=840sin(∠BAC)​​

Applying the Pythagorean Theorem yields

∠BAC=90°​⟺∣AB∣2+∣AC∣2=∣BC∣2⟺∣BC∣=58⟺x=29​​

Therefore, it is easy to prove that r=840,s=29. Therefore, p+q+r+s=911.

Problem 3

The measures of the smallest angles of three different right triangles sum to 90°. All three triangles have side lengths that are primitive Pythagorean triples. Two of them are 3−4−5 and 5−12−13. What is the perimeter of the third triangle?

Solution

Let the smallest angles of these triangles be α, β and γ, respectively. Then

tan(γ)​=tan(90°−α−β)=cot(α+β)=cot(α)+cot(β)cot(α)cot(β)−1​=5633​​​

Therefore, it is easy to prove that the third triangle is a 33−56−65 triangle. Therefore, the perimeter of the third triangle is 33+56+65=154.

Problem 4

Let △ABC be a triangle with integer side lengths and the property that ∠B=2∠A. What is the least possible perimeter of such a triangle?

Solution

Applying the Law of Sines yields

∣BC∣∣AC∣​=sin(∠A)sin(∠B)​

Therefore,

∠B=2∠A​⟹sin(∠B)=sin(2∠A)⟺∣BC∣∣AC∣​=sin(∠A)sin(2∠A)​⟺∣BC∣∣AC∣​=2cos(∠A)​​

Applying the Law of Cosines yields

cos(∠A)=2∣AB∣∣AC∣∣AB∣2+∣AC∣2−∣BC∣2​

Therefore,

∠B=2∠A​⟹∣BC∣∣AC∣​=∣AB∣∣AC∣∣AB∣2+∣AC∣2−∣BC∣2​⟺∣AB∣=∣BC∣∨∣AC∣2=∣BC∣(∣AB∣+∣BC∣)​​

Therefore, it is easy to prove that if ∣AC∣<7, the only triangle with integer side lengths and the property that ∠B=2∠A is the triangle such that ∣AB∣=5∧∣AC∣=6∧∣BC∣=4. The perimeter of this triangle is 5+6+4=15.

Applying the Triangle Inequality yields

∣AB∣+∣BC∣>∣AC∣

Therefore, if ∣AC∣≥7,

∣AB∣+∣BC∣>∣AC∣​⟺∣AB∣+∣AC∣+∣BC∣>2∣AC∣⟹∣AB∣+∣AC∣+∣BC∣≥15​​

Therefore, the least perimeter is 15.

Problem 5

A right pyramid has regular octagon ABCDEFGH with side length 1 as its base and apex V. Segments AV and DV are perpendicular. What is the square of the height of the pyramid?

Solution

Let O be the center of the octagon, X be a point on BC such that OX⊥BC, Y be a point on DE such that OY⊥DE. Set up a coordinate system by taking O as the origin, OX as the x-axis, OY as the y-axis, and OV as the z-axis. Then it is easy to prove that

OA=(21​,−21+2​​,0),OD=(21​,−21+2​​,0),OV=(0,0,∣OV∣)

Therefore,

AV​=OV−OA=(−21​,21+2​​,∣OV∣)​​ DV​=OV−OD=(−21​,−21+2​​,∣OV∣)​​

Therefore,

AV⊥DV​⟺AV⋅DV=0⟺−21+2​​+∣OV∣2=0⟺∣OV∣2=21+2​​​​

Therefore, the square of the height is 21+2​​.

Problem 6

What is the number of ordered triples ⟨a,b,c⟩ of positive integers, with a≤b≤c≤9, such that there exists a (non-degenerate) triangle △ABC with an integer inradius for which a, b and c are the lengths of the altitudes from A to BC, B to AC, and C to AB, respectively?

Solution

Let O be the incenter of △ABC, r be the length of the inradius of △ABC. Then

[△ABC]​=[△AOB]+[△AOC]+[△BOC]=21​(∣AB∣+∣AC∣+∣BC∣)r​​

Since [△ABC]=21​∣AB∣c, it follows that

cr​=∣AB∣+∣AC∣+∣BC∣∣AB∣​

Since [△ABC]=21​∣AC∣b, it follows that

br​=∣AB∣+∣AC∣+∣BC∣∣AC∣​

Since [△ABC]=21​∣BC∣a, it follows that

ar​=∣AB∣+∣AC∣+∣BC∣∣BC∣​

Therefore,

a1​+b1​+c1​=r1​

Therefore,

r∈Z⟺a1​+b1​+c1​1​∈Z

Therefore, it is easy to prove that all ordered triples are ⟨3,3,3⟩, ⟨6,6,6⟩, and ⟨9,9,9⟩. Therefore, the number of ordered triples is 3.

Problem 7

Cyclic quadrilateral ABCD has lengths ∣BC∣=∣CD∣=3 and ∣AD∣=5 with ∠ADC=120°. What is the length of the shorter diagonal of ABCD?

Solution

Applying the Law of Cosines yields

∣AC∣2=∣AD∣2+∣CD∣2−2∣AD∣∣CD∣cos(∠ADC) ∣AC∣2=∣AD∣2+∣CD∣2−2∣AD∣∣CD∣cos(∠ADC)⟺∣AC∣=7

Applying the Law of Cosines yields

∣AC∣2=∣AB∣2+∣BC∣2−2∣AB∣∣BC∣cos(∠ABC)

Since

∠ABC​=180°−∠ADC=60°​​

it follows that

∣AC∣2=∣AB∣2+∣BC∣2−2∣AB∣∣BC∣cos(∠ABC)⟺∣AB∣=8

Applying Ptolemy’s Theorem yields

∣AC∣∣BD∣=∣AB∣∣CD∣+∣AD∣∣BC∣ ∣AC∣∣BD∣=∣AB∣∣CD∣+∣AD∣∣BC∣⟺∣BD∣=739​

Therefore, the length of the shorter diagonal is min{∣AC∣,∣BD∣}=739​.

Problem 8

On top of a rectangular card with sides of length 1 and 2+3​, an identical card is placed so that two of their diagonals line up, as shown (AC, in this case). Continue the process, adding a third card to the second, and so on, lining up successive diagonals after rotating clockwise. In total, how many cards must be used until a vertex of a new card lands exactly on the vertex B in the figure?

Solution

Applying the Pythagorean Theorem yields

∣AC∣​=∣AB∣2+∣BC∣2​=22+3​​​​

Let D be the midpoint of AC, then

∣AD∣​=21​∣AC∣=2+3​​​​ ∣BD∣​=∣AD∣=2+3​​​​

Applying the Law of Cosines yields

∣AB∣2=∣AD∣2+∣BD∣2−2∣AD∣∣BD∣cos(∠ADB) ∣AB∣2=∣AD∣2+∣BD∣2−2∣AD∣∣BD∣cos(∠ADB)​⟺cos(∠ADB)=23​​⟺∠ADB=30°​​

Therefore, it is easy to prove that 6 cards must be used.

Problem 9

Triangle △ABC has side lengths in arithmetic progression, and the smallest side has length 6. If the triangle has an angle of 120°, what is the area of △ABC?

Solution

Wlog, assume ∣AB∣≤∣AC∣≤∣BC∣, then it is easy to prove that ∣AB∣=6 and ∠A=120°.

Applying the Law of Cosines yields

∣BC∣2=∣AB∣2+∣AC∣2−2∣AB∣∣AC∣cos(∠A)

Let d be common difference of the arithmetic progression, then

∣BC∣2=∣AB∣2+∣AC∣2−2∣AB∣∣AC∣cos(∠A)⟺d=4

Therefore, ∣AC∣=10.

Therefore,

[△ABC]​=21​sin(∠A)∣AB∣∣AC∣=153​​​

Problem 10

A regular pentagon with area 1+5​ is printed on paper and cut out. The five vertices of the pentagon are folded into the center of the pentagon, creating a smaller pentagon. What is the area of the new pentagon?

Solution

Let ABCDE be the pentagon, O be the center of ABCDE, M be the midpoint of OA, N be a point on AB such that ON⊥AB, x be area of the new pentagon. Then it is easy to prove that

x[ABCDE]​​=(∣OM∣∣ON∣​)2=(∣OA∣2∣ON∣​)2=(2sin(∠AON))2=4sin(54°)2​​

Since

cos(54°)=sin(36°)​⟺cos(18°)3−3sin(18°)2cos(18°)=2sin(18°)cos(18°)⟺4sin(18°)2+2sin(18°)−1=0⟺sin(18°)=4−1+5​​​​

it follows that

sin(54°)​=cos(36°)=1−2sin(18°)2=41+5​​​​

Therefore,

x​=4sin(54°)2[ABCDE]​=−1+5​​​

Problem 11

Let △PQR be a triangle with ∠P=75° and ∠Q=60°. A regular hexagon ABCDEF with side length 1 is drawn inside △PQR so that side AB lies on PQ​, side CD lies on QR​, and one of the remaining vertices lies on PR. There are positive integers a, b, c, and d such that the area of △PQR can be expressed in the form da+bc​​, where a and d are relatively prime, and c is not divisible by the square of any prime. Find a+b+c+d.

Solution

Applying the Law of Sines yields

∣PF∣∣PA∣​​=sin(∠APF)sin(∠PFA)​=sin(75°)sin(45°)​​​

Since

sin(75°)​=cos(15°)=21+cos(30°)​​=42​+6​​​​

it follows that

∣PA∣=−1+3​

Therefore,

∣PQ∣​=∣PA∣+∣AB∣+∣BQ∣=1+3​​​

Since

∠PAF=∠Q⟺△PAF∼△PQR

it follows that

[△PAF][△PQR]​​=(∣PA∣∣PQ∣​)2=7+43​​​

Since

[△PAF]​=21​sin(∠PAF)∣PA∣∣AF∣=43−3​​​​

it follows that

[△PQR]=49+53​​

Therefore, a+b+c+d=21.

Problem 12

In the figure below, semicircles with centers at A and B and with radii 2 and 1, respectively, are drawn in the interior of, and sharing bases with, a semicircle with diameter JK. The two smaller semicircles are externally tangent to each other and internally tangent to the largest semicircle. A circle centered at P is drawn externally tangent to the two smaller semicircles and internally tangent to the largest semicircle. What is the radius of the circle centered at P?

Solution

Let O be the center of the largest semicircle, r be the length of the radius of ⊙P, then it is easy to prove that ∣AB∣=3,∣OA∣=1,∣OB∣=2,∣AP∣=2+r,∣BP∣=1+r,∣OP∣=3−r.

Applying Steward’s Theorem yields

∣AP∣2∣OB∣+∣BP∣2∣OA∣=∣OP∣2∣AB∣+∣OA∣∣OB∣∣AB∣ ∣AP∣2∣OB∣+∣BP∣2∣OA∣=(∣OP∣2+∣OA∣∣OB∣)∣AB∣⟺r=76​

Problem 13

Point B is on AC with ∣AB∣=9 and ∣BC∣=21. Point D is not on AC so that ∣AD∣=∣CD∣, and ∣AD∣ and ∣BD∣ are integers. Let s be the sum of all possible perimeters of △ACD. Find s.

Solution

Let E be the midpoint of AC, then applying the Pythagorean Theorem yields

∣AD∣2−∣AE∣2=∣DE∣2,∣BD∣2−∣BE∣2=∣DE∣2

Therefore,

(∣AD∣−∣BD∣)(∣AD∣+∣BD∣)=189

Therefore, it is easy to prove that

∣AD∣∈Z∧∣BD∣∈Z⟺∣AD∣=95∨∣AD∣=33∨∣AD∣=17

Therefore, s=380.

Problem 14

In △ABC, ∣AB∣=13, ∣AC∣=14, and ∣BC∣=15. Point D is on BC with ∣CD∣=6. Point E is on BC such that ∠BAE=∠CAD. Given that ∣BE∣=qp​ where p and q are relatively prime positive integers, find q.

Solution

∣CE∣∣BE∣​​=[△ACE][△ABE]​=21​sin(∠CAE)∣AC∣∣AE∣21​sin(∠BAE)∣AB∣∣AE∣​=14sin(∠CAE)13sin(∠BAE)​​​

Since

∣CD∣∣BD∣​​=[△ACD][△ABD]​=21​sin(∠CAD)∣AC∣∣AD∣21​sin(∠BAD)∣AB∣∣AD∣​=14sin(∠CAD)13sin(∠BAD)​​​

it follows that

sin(∠CAE)sin(∠BAE)​​=sin(∠BAD)sin(∠CAD)​=14∣BD∣13∣CD∣​=2113​​​

Therefore,

∣CE∣∣BE∣​=294169​ ∣CE∣∣BE∣​=294169​​⟺∣BE∣=463169​∣BC∣⟺∣BE∣=4632535​​​

Therefore, q=463.

Problem 15

A paper equilateral triangle △ABC has side length 12. The paper triangle is folded so that vertex A touches a point on side BC a distance 9 from point B. The length of the line segment along which the triangle is folded can be written as nmp​​, where m, n, and p are positive integers, m and n are relatively prime, and p is not divisible by the square of any prime. Find m+n+p.

Solution

Let D be the point on BC, M be the point on AB. Then applying the Law of Cosines yields

∣MD∣2=∣MB∣2+∣BD∣2+2∣MB∣∣BD∣cos(∠B) ∣MD∣2=∣MB∣2+∣BD∣2+2∣MB∣∣BD∣cos(∠B)⟺∣AM∣=539​

Let N be the point on AC, then applying the Law of Cosines yields

∣ND∣2=∣NC∣2+∣CD∣2+2∣NC∣∣CD∣cos(∠C) ∣ND∣2=∣NC∣2+∣CD∣2+2∣NC∣∣CD∣cos(∠C)⟺∣AN∣=739​

Applying the Law of Cosines yields

∣MN∣​=∣AM∣2+∣AN∣2+2∣AM∣∣AN∣cos(∠A)​=353939​​​​

Therefore, m+n+p=113.

Problem 16

Let △ABC be an acute triangle with circumcenter O and centroid G. Let X be the intersection of the line tangent to the circumcircle of △ABC at A and the line perpendicular to GO at G. Let Y be the intersection of lines XG and BC. Given that the measures of ∠ABC, ∠ACB, and ∠XOY are in the ratio 13:2:17, the degree measure of ∠BAC can be written as nm​, where m and n are relatively prime positive integers. Find m+n.

Solution

Since ∠XGO=∠XAO, it follows that XOGA is cyclic. Since XOGA is cyclic, it follows that ∠GAO=∠GXO.

Let M be the midpoint of BC, then since ∠YMO+∠YGO=180°, it follows that MOGY is cyclic. Since MOGY is cyclic, it follows that ∠GMO=∠GYO.

∠GAO=∠GXO∧∠GMO=∠GYO​⟺△AOM∼△XOY⟹∠AOM=∠XOY​​

Therefore,

∠BAC​=21​∠BOC=∠BOM=∠AOM−∠AOB=∠XOY−2∠ACB​​

Therefore,

∠ABC:∠ACB:∠XOY=13:2:17​⟺∠BAC:∠ABC:∠ACB=13:13:2⟹∠BAC=7585​°​​

Therefore, m+n=592.

Problem 17

In △ABC we have ∣AB∣=7,∣AC∣=8,∣BC∣=9. Point D is on the circumscribed circle of the triangle so that AD bisects ∠BAC. What is the value of ∣CD∣∣AD∣​?

Solution

∠BAD=∠CAD​⟺∠BCD=∠CBD⟺∣BD∣=∣CD∣​​

Therefore, applying Ptolemy’s Theorem yields

∣AB∣∣CD∣+∣AC∣∣BD∣=∣AD∣∣BC∣⟺∣CD∣∣AD∣​=35​

Problem 18

Two externally tangent circles ω1​ and ω2​ have centers O1​ and O2​, respectively. A third circle Ω passing through O1​ and O2​ intersects ω1​ at B and C and ω2​ at A and D, as shown. Suppose that ∣AB∣=2,∣O1​O2​∣=15,∣CD∣=16, and ABO1​CDO2​ is a convex hexagon. Find the area of this hexagon.

Solution

Let A′ and B′ be the reflections of A and B, respectively, about the perpendicular bisector of O1​O2​​. Then it is easy to prove that A′ and B′ are on Ω and O1​O2​AB≅O2​O1​A′B′.

∣O1​A′∣​=∣O2​A∣=∣O2​D∣​​

Since

∣O1​A′∣=∣O2​D∣​⟺O1​A′​=O2​D​⟺∠O1​O2​A′=∠O2​O1​D⟺O2​A′​∥O1​D​​​

it follows that O1​A′O2​D is an isosceles trapezoid.

Therefore,

∣A′D∣​=∣O1​O2​∣=15​​ ∣O2​B′∣​=∣O1​B∣=∣O1​C∣​​

Since

∣O2​B′∣=∣O1​C∣​⟺O2​B′​=O1​C​⟺∠O1​B′C=∠O2​CB′⟺O1​B′​∥O2​C​​​

it follows that O1​B′O2​C is an isosceles trapezoid.

Therefore,

∣B′C∣​=∣O1​O2​∣=15​​ O1​A′​=O2​D​⟺∠O1​CA′=∠O2​B′D O1​C​=O2​B′​⟺∠O1​A′C=∠O2​DB′

Since

∠O1​CA′=∠O2​B′D∧∠O1​A′C=∠O2​DB′∧∣O1​A′∣=∣O2​D∣​⟺△O1​A′C≅△O2​DB′⟹∣A′C∣=∣B′D∣⟺A′C=B′D⟺∠A′B′C=∠B′CD⟺A′B′∥CD​​

it follows that A′B′DC is an isosceles trapezoid.

Therefore, applying Ptolemy’s Theorem yields

∣A′B′∣∣CD∣+∣A′C∣∣B′D∣=∣A′D∣∣B′C∣ ∣A′B′∣∣CD∣+∣A′C∣∣B′D∣=∣A′D∣∣B′C∣⟺∣A′C∣=193​

Therefore, applying the Law of Cosines yields

cos(∠A′B′C)​=2∣A′B′∣∣B′C∣∣A′B′∣2+∣B′C∣2−∣A′C∣2​=53​​​ cos(∠A′B′C)=53​⟺sin(∠A′B′C)=54​

Let E be perpendicular foot from C to A′B′, then it follows that

∣CE∣​=∣B′C∣sin(∠A′B′C)=12​​

Therefore,

[A′B′DC]​=21​(∣A′B′∣+∣CD∣)∣CE∣=108​​

Let r1​ and r2​ be the radius of ω1​ and ω2​, respectively. Then it follows that

r1​+r2​​=∣O1​O2​∣=15​​

Applying the Law of Cosines yields

∣A′C∣2=∣O1​A′∣2+∣O1​C∣2−2∣O1​A′∣∣O1​C∣cos(∠A′O1​C)

Since

cos(∠A′O1​C)​=cos(180°−∠A′B′C)=−cos(∠A′B′C)=−53​​​

it follows that

r1​r2​=40

Since

sin(∠A′O1​C)​=cos(180°−∠A′B′C)=sin(∠A′B′C)=54​​​

it follows that

[△O1​A′C]​=21​sin(∠A′O1​C)∣O1​A′∣∣O1​C∣=52​r1​r2​=16​​

Therefore,

[△O2​DB′]​=[△O1​A′C]=16​​

Therefore,

[ABO1​CDO2​]​=[O1​O2​AB]+[O1​O2​CD]=[O2​O1​A′B′]+[O1​O2​CD]=[O1​A′B′O2​DC]=[A′B′DC]+[△O1​A′C]+[△O2​DB′]=140​​

Problem 19

Quadrilateral ABCD is inscribed in ⊙O and has side lengths ∣AB∣=3, ∣BC∣=2, ∣CD∣=6, and ∣AD∣=8. Let X and Y be points on BD such that ∣BD∣∣DX∣​=41​ and ∣BD∣∣BY∣​=3611​. Let E be the intersection of line AX and the line through Y parallel to AD. Let F be the intersection of the line CX and the line through E parallel to AC. Let G be the point on ⊙O other than C that lies on line CX. What is ∣FX∣∣GX∣?

Solution

EY∥AG​⟺△ADX∼△EYX⟹∣EX∣∣AX∣​=XYDX​⟺∣EX∣∣AX∣​=169​​​

Therefore,

AC∥EF​⟺△ACX∼△EFX⟹∣FX∣∣CX∣​=∣EX∣∣AX∣​⟺∣FX∣∣CX∣​=169​​​

Applying the Law of Cosines yields

∣BD∣2​=∣AB∣2+∣AD∣2−2∣AB∣∣AD∣cos(∠BAD)=73−48cos(∠BAD)​​

Applying the Law of Cosines yields

∣BD∣2​=∣BC∣2+∣CD∣2−2∣BC∣∣CD∣cos(∠BCD)=40−24cos(∠BCD)=40+24cos(∠BAD)​​

Therefore,

∣BD∣=51​

Therefore,

∣DX∣​=41​∣BD∣=451​​​​

Therefore,

∣BX∣​=∣BD∣−∣DX∣=4351​​​​

Applying the Power of a Point Theorem yields

∣CX∣∣GX∣​=∣BX∣∣DX∣=16153​​​

Therefore,

∣FX∣∣GX∣​=∣CX∣∣FX∣​∣CX∣∣GX∣=17​​

Problem 20

In △ABC, ∠A=40°, ∣AB∣=10, and ∣AC∣=6. Points D and E lie on AB and AC respectively. What is the minimum possible value of ∣BE∣+∣DE∣+∣CD∣?

Solution

Let B′ be the reflection of B about AC, then ∣B′E∣=∣BE∣. Let C′ be the reflection of C about AB, then ∣C′D∣=∣CD∣.

Since applying the Law of Cosines yields

∣B′C′∣​=∣AB′∣2+∣AC′∣2−2∣AB′∣∣AC′∣cos(∠B′AC′)​=14​​

it follows that

min(∣BE∣+∣DE∣+∣CD∣)​=min(∣B′E∣+∣DE∣+∣C′D∣)=∣B′C′∣=14​​

Problem 21

Cube ABCDEFGH, labeled as shown below, has edge length of 1 and is cut by a plane passing through vertex D and the midpoints M and N of AB and CG respectively. The plane divides the cube into two solids. The volume of the larger of the two solids can be written in the form qp​, where p and q are relatively prime positive integers. Find p+q.

Solution

Set up a coordinate system by taking D as the origin, DA as the x-axis, DC as the y-axis, and DH as the z-axis, then M=(1,21​,0),N=(0,1,21​). Therefore, the plane is z=−41​x+21​y.

Therefore, the volume of one of the solids is

∫01​∫21​x1​(−41​x+21​y)dydx=487​

Therefore, the volume of the larger solid is 1−487​=4841​. Therefore, p+q=89.

Problem 22

Tetrahedron ABCD has ∣AB∣=5, ∣AC∣=3, ∣BC∣=4, ∣AD∣=3, ∣BD∣=4, and ∣CD∣=5122​​. What is the volume of the tetrahedron?

Solution

Applying the Pythagorean Theorem yields

∣AB∣2=∣AC∣2+∣BC∣2⟺∠ACB=90°

Let E be the perpendicular foot from C to AB, then

∣CE∣​=∣AB∣∣AC∣∣BC∣​=512​​​

Similarly, it follows that ∣DE∣=512​.

Applying the Pythagorean Theorem yields

∣CD∣2=∣CE∣2+∣DE∣2⟺∠CED=90°

Therefore,

[ABCD]​=31​[△ABC]∣DE∣=61​∣AC∣∣BC∣∣DE∣=524​​​

Problem 23

Inside a right circular cone with base radius 5 and height 12 are three congruent spheres with radius r. Each sphere is tangent to the other two spheres and also tangent to the base and side of the cone. What is r?

Solution

Let O be the center of one of the spheres, D be the point where that sphere is tangent to the base, E be the point where that sphere is tangent to the side, B be the center of the base, A be the point such that AB is a radius of the base containing D, C be the vertex of the cone. Then applying the Pythagorean Theorem yields

∣AC∣​=∣AB∣2+∣BC∣2​=13​​ OD⊥AB∧OE⊥AC∧∣OD∣=∣OE∣⟹∠OAB=∠OAC

Therefore, let F be the intersection of OA and BC, then applying the Angle Bisector Theorem yields

∣CF∣∣BF∣​=∣AC∣∣AB∣​ ∣CF∣∣BF∣​=∣AC∣∣AB∣​⟺∣BF∣=310​

Therefore,

OD∥BF​⟺△OAD∼△FAB⟹∣AB∣∣AD∣​=∣BF∣∣OD∣​⟺∣AD∣=23​r​​

Let X,Y be the center of the other spheres, respectively, then it is easy to prove that △OXY is an equilateral triangle with center B and side length 2r.

Therefore, it is easy to prove that ∣BD∣=323​​r.

Therefore,

∣AD∣+∣BD∣=∣AB∣⟺r=1190−403​​

Problem 24

Three numbers in the interval [0,1] are chosen independently and at random. What is the probability that the chosen numbers are the side lengths of a triangle with positive area?

Solution

Let the numbers be x, y, and z, respectively, then applying the Triangle Inequality yields x, y, and z form a triangle iff

y+z>x∧x+z>y∧x+y>z

Therefore, the probability that x, y, and z form a triangle is

Pr[y+z>x∧x+z>y∧x+y>z]

Applying the Law of Total Probability yields

Pr[y+z>x∧x+z>y∧x+y>z]​=Pr[y+z>x∣x>y∧x>z]=Pr[x>y∧x>z]Pr[y+z>x∧x>y∧x>z]​=3∫01​∫01​∫01​[y+z>x∧x>y∧x>z]dzdydx=3∫01​∫0x​∫x−yx​dzdydx=21​​​

Problem 25

Real numbers x, y, and z are chosen independently and at random from the interval [0,n] for some positive integer n. The probability that no two of x, y, and z are within 1 unit of each other is greater than 21​. What is the smallest possible value of n?

Solution

Since it is easy to prove that the probability is 0 when n=1, it follows that n≥2.

Assume n≥2.

Applying the Law of Total Probability yields

Pr[∣x−y∣>1∧∣x−z∣>1∧∣y−z∣>1]​=Pr[x−y>1∧y−z>1∣x>y>z]=Pr[x>y>z]Pr[x−y>1∧y−z>1]​=n36​∫0n​∫0n​∫0n​[x−y>1∧y−z>1]dzdydx=n36​∫2n​∫1x−1​∫0y−1​dzdydx=n3(n−2)3​​​

Since

n3(n−2)3​>21​⟺n≥10

it follows that the smallest possible value of n is 10.

Problem 26

Equilateral △ABC has side length 600. Points P and Q lie outside the plane of △ABC and are on opposite sides of the plane. Furthermore, ∣PA∣=∣PB∣=∣PC∣, and ∣QA∣=∣QB∣=∣QC∣, and the planes of △PAB and △QAB form a 120° diheral angle. There is a point O whose distance from each of A,B,C,P,Q is d. Find d.

Solution

Let D be the center of △ABC, then it is easy to prove that PQ​⊥△ABC and the perpendicular foot is D.

Since ∣OA∣=∣OB∣=∣OC∣ and ∣OP∣=∣OQ∣, it follows that O is on PQ​.

Therefore, applying the Pythagorean Theorem yields

∣OA∣2=∣OD∣2+∣AD∣2

Let x=∣PD∣,y=∣QD∣, then

∣OA∣2=∣OD∣2+∣AD∣2​⟺(2x+y​)2=(2x−y​)2+(2003​)2⟺xy=120000​​

Let E be the perpendicular foot from D to AB, then

∠PEQ=120°​⟺∠PED+∠QED=120°⟺tan(∠PED+∠QED)=−3​⟺1−tan(∠PED)tan(∠QED)tan(∠PED)+tan(∠QED)​=−3​⟺1−1003​x​1003​y​1003​x​+1003​y​​=−3​⟺x+y=100xy​−300⟺x+y=900​​

Therefore,

d​=∣OP∣=2x+y​=450​​

Problem 27

A 4×4×h rectangular box contains a sphere of radius 2 and eight smaller spheres of radius 1. The smaller spheres are each tangent to three sides of the box, and the larger sphere is tangent to each of the smaller spheres. What is h?

Solution

Let A be the center of the larger sphere, B,C,D,E be the centers of the smaller spheres below the larger sphere, respectively. Then it is easy to prove that ∣BC∣=∣CD∣=∣DE∣=∣BE∣=2 and ∣AB∣=∣AC∣=∣AD∣=∣AE∣=3.

Therefore, let O be the center of BCDE, then it is easy to prove that OA⊥BCDE.

Therefore, applying the Pythagorean Theorem yields

∣OA∣​=∣AB∣2−∣OB∣2​=7​​​

Therefore, it is easy to prove that h=2+27​.

Problem 28

A sphere is inscribed in a truncated right circular cone as shown. The volume of the truncated cone is twice that of the sphere. What is the ratio of the radius of the bottom base of the truncated cone to the radius of the top base of the truncated cone?

Solution

Let r be the radius of the top base of the truncated cone, R be the radius of the bottom base of the truncated cone, s be the radius of the sphere. Then applying the Pythagorean Theorem yields

(R+r)2=(R−r)2+(2s)2 (R+r)2=(R−r)2+(2s)2⟺s2=Rr

Since the volume of the truncated cone is twice the volume of the sphere, it follows that

2⋅34​πs3=31​π(2s)(R2+Rr+r2) 2⋅34​πs3=31​π(2s)(R2+Rr+r2)​⟺4s2=R2+Rr+r2⟺4Rr=R2+Rr+r2⟺rR​=23+5​​​​

Problem 29

Suppose that △ABC is an equilateral triangle of side length s, with property that there is a unique point P inside the triangle such that ∣AP∣=1, ∣BP∣=3​, and ∣CP∣=2. What is s?

Solution

Let Q be the point obtained by rotating P 60° counterclockwise about A. Then

∠PAQ​=∠CAP+∠CAQ=∠CAP+∠BAP=∠BAC=60°​​ ∣AP∣=∣AQ∣∧∠PAQ=60°⟺∣PQ∣=1

Therefore, applying the Pythagorean Theorem yields

∣CP∣2=∣CQ∣2+∣PQ∣2⟺∠CQP=90°

Since

∠CPQ​=arccos(∣CP∣∣PQ∣​)=60°​​

it follows that

∠APC​=∠APQ+∠CPQ=120°​​

Therefore, applying the Law of Cosines yields

s​=∣AC∣=∣AP∣2+∣CP∣2−2∣AP∣∣CP∣cos(∠APC)​=7​​​
